com.climbwithyourfeet.clustering

Class ClosestPair

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.climbwithyourfeet.clustering.ClosestPair

  • public class ClosestPair
extends java.lang.Object
    Find the closest pair of points in a set of points by using divide and conquer to reduce the number of comparisons From pseudocode in Intro to Algorithms by Cormen et al. runtime complexity is ~ O(N lg N).
    Author:
    nichole

    • Nested Class Summary

      runtime complexity: O(N) plus a small fraction of points contributing O(m lg m) for a sort
      protected ClosestPair.ClosestPairFloat divide(java.util.List<PairFloat> p, java.util.List<PairFloat> x, java.util.List<PairFloat> y)

      • findClosestPair

        public ClosestPair.ClosestPairFloat findClosestPair(java.util.List<java.lang.Float> xPoints,
                                                    java.util.List<java.lang.Float> yPoints)
        find the closest pair within the x,y set of points. note that the given arrays will have their item orders altered.
        Parameters:
        xPoints -
        yPoints -
        Returns:
        returns 5 items in array: shortest distance between pairs, pt1 x, pt1 y, pt2 x, pt2 y

      • divide

        protected ClosestPair.ClosestPairFloat divide(java.util.List<PairFloat> p,
                                              java.util.List<PairFloat> x,
                                              java.util.List<PairFloat> y)
        use divide and conquer to find the pair of points with the smallest separation. note that x and y have to contain objects that are the same instance as the objects in p.
        Parameters:
        p - should be ordered left to right already
        x -
        y -
        Returns:
